text: While Broadway fans might be propelled to return to the musical soundtrack, the performances and humour remain strong enough to allow Mean Girls (2024) to stand on its own merits.

Mean Girls had a tough act to follow with the inevitable comparison to the original film but it is a film that works for fans of the musicals and one that I thought was a lot of fun to revisit the 2004 film 20 years later.
While this new iteration offers a fresh perspective and modern flair, it doesn’t quite deliver the same sharp wit or memorable moments that made the original so timeless.

Without quite living up to its predecessor, which remains in the collective memory as a superior and iconic teen film, the new version of "Mean Girls" delivers on what it sets out to do. [Full Review in Spanish]
While “Mean Girls” has plenty of humor and fun to offer, its strong points simply make its weaker moments that much more frustrating.
It all just reads like a competition to see which corporation can get the most screen time and once you notice it, it's impossible to unsee.
Mean Girls is a mostly fun musical that desperately needs to shed its fat plotline.
Mean Girls (2024) does not seek to replace its big screen predecessor from 20 years ago, but rather complement it

...in order to make a musical great, it must contain 1) fantastic musical numbers, 2) phenomenal choreography, and 3) the former two must work cohesively with the plot. In my opinion, Mean Girls failed in all three categories.
Despite some admirable merits, it just doesn’t spark in the same way that the 2004 version did.
This isn't fetch, but it's really trying to make fetch happen. (Stop trying to make fetch happen).
This remake of Mean Girls serves mainly as an update, as the in-universe setting catches up to technology and the challenges of being a team in this day and age.
If "not your mother's Mean Girls" means it's a departure from the problematic jokes that were a hallmark of the noughties, then it certainly delivers on that promise for Gen Z.
The effort to make the movie musical work on its own terms while still paying homage to the original is too overtly strenuous to be successful, making this Mean Girls more of a chore than a pleasure.
With the exceptions of Auli’i Cravalho (Janis) and Jaquel Spivey (Damian), there isn’t anyone here who comes close to matching the superior work of their predecessors.

It bursts with life from start to finish, with funny, fast-paced songs; comically over-the-top performances; and a relentlessly witty script from Tina Fey. ...  The revelation here is Rapp, a force of nature as the comically vampish Regina.
Now the jokes are all recycled, and the characters never really get a chance to be... the characters. It's modestly amusing.
Even though Rapp, Cravalho and Spivey steal the show and every scene they inhabit making this remake fun - despite painful pacing of the narrative

Mean Girls sees itself as the 2004 movie’s young Gen-Z cousin. Don’t get me wrong, it’s a fun, enjoyable movie with plenty to love for fans of the musical. However, it’s difficult to see why fans of the 2004 film wouldn’t just watch that movie.
The staging of the songs from the Broadway show is consistently inventive, something that a surprising number of movie musicals still struggle with after all these years.
